column1: Delano ( də-LAY-noh) is a city in Kern County
column3: United States. Delano is located 31 miles (50 km) north-northwest of Bakersfield at an elevation of 315 feet (96 m). The population was 53
column6: 824 in 2000. It is Kern County's second-largest city after Bakersfield.

column1: Agriculture is Delano's major industry. The area is particularly well known as a center for the growing of table grapes.  Delano is also home to two California state prisons
column2: North Kern State Prison and Kern Valley State Prison. The Voice of America once operated its largest
column3: most powerful shortwave broadcast facility outside Delano at 35°45′15″N 119°17′7″W. The Voice of America ceased broadcasts in October 2007
column4: citing a changing political mission
column6: and changes in technology.Delano's two school districts currently operate eight elementary schools
column8: three comprehensive high schools and two alternative high schools. The city has its own police department and contracts with the Kern County Fire Department for fire services
column9: EMS services are privately provided by local company

column4: not because the railroad passed through the town but because the railroad coming south from San Francisco terminated at Delano. The name was officially given by the Southern Pacific Railroad in honor of Columbus Delano
column5: at the time the Secretary of the Interior (1870-1875) for the United States. The first post office opened in 1874. Delano incorporated in 1913.The town started with a boom. With Delano as the southern terminus of the railroad
column6: it became the headquarters for hundreds of workmen who were building the railroad into town
column7: and who eventually built the railroad into Bakersfield the following year. Meanwhile
column8: the merchandise that formerly was trucked south from Visalia to Bakersfield and then to Walker Pass
column11: now coming via freight from the south
column13: was likewise trucked in by ox or mule team. Great loads of bullion were delivered here from the mines in the mountains. Delano became the northern terminus for the passenger stages that ran south to Bakersfield and Los Angeles. The fare from Bakersfield to Delano was $7.00.

column1: Delano was a major hub of farm worker organization efforts and Chicano political movements. Filipino immigrants Philip Vera Cruz and Larry Dulay Itliong were instrumental in shaping the direction of farm worker movement in the 1950s.

column3: Larry Itliong and other Filipino leaders led the predominantly Filipino Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee (AWOC) in a "walk off" from table grape farms
column4: now known as the Delano grape strike. The strikers' goal was to improve farm workers' wages and working conditions. The National Farm Workers' Association (NFWA)
column5: a largely Hispanic union led by Cesar Chavez
column6: joined the strike within a week. During the strike
column7: the two groups joined forces and formed the United Farm Workers of America (UFW). By 1970
column8: the UFW won a contract with major grape growers across California.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 14.4 square miles (37 km2); over 99% of which is land.

column1: Delano's climate is typical of the San Joaquin Valley. It is located within a desert climatic zone with Mediterranean features. The city receives 7.51 in (191 mm) of rainfall annually
column2: mainly in the winter. The weather is hot and dry during the summer and cool and damp in winter. Frequent winter ground fog known regionally as tule fog can obscure vision. Record temperatures range between 115 °F (46 °C) (2006) and 14 °F (−10 °C) (1990).

column1: The Delano Area Rapid Transit (DART) provides fixed route bus service on four routes and demand responsive public transportation service (Dial-A- Ride) to the residents of Delano and the immediate county area surrounding the city within the boundaries of State Route 43 to the west
column2: County Line Road to the north
column4: and Kyte Avenue to the east.

column1: The Delano Municipal Airport is an uncontrolled airfield with a 5
column2: 651 foot runway and light aviation services
column3: and is open to the public. There is no scheduled airline service
column4: but the airport serves a variety of other significant users. Many military
column7: and other flying services operate from the airport on a regular basis.

column1: Various private taxi services are available throughout the city of Delano.

The Cinco De Mayo Fiesta celebrates Mexican culture with live entertainment and a carnival at Memorial Park. This four-day celebrations commemorates Cinco de Mayo.Delano is home to the Annual Philippine Weekend festival which celebrates Filipino Culture through performing arts and cultural activities. The festival aims to continue the preservation of the art and history of the Philippines. The festival includes a pork adobo cook-off
column4: basketball tournament

column1: The nearby Sequoia National Forest includes a vast number of Giant Sequoia groves
column3: scenic canyons and meadows. The Tule Elk State Reserve provides protection to the Tule elk which in the past were in danger of extinction. Lake Woollomes is a popular location. The Kern National Wildlife Refuge is nearby. The Shirley Meadows Ski Area
column4: located on Green Horn Mountain provides skiing opportunities. The nearby Kern River and Isabella Lake are popular during the summer.
